conclusion: Analyze how the orientation and movement of a metal rod affect the induced EMF in different configurations of magnetic fields.

The image shows a metal rod initially aligned perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field. When the rod moves at speed v, an EMF ε is induced. The rod is then bent into two equal-length segments that are perpendicular to each other and placed in the plane perpendicular to the magnetic field. The rod moves at the same speed v along the angle bisector of the included angle between the two segments, inducing an EMF ε'.
The problem involves a metal rod in a uniform magnetic field. Initially, the rod is perpendicular to the magnetic field, inducing an EMF ε when it moves at speed v.
The EMF ε induced in the initial configuration is determined by the rod's length L, magnetic field B, and speed v through the equation ε = BLv.

The rod is then bent into two equal-length segments, each of length L/2. When the rod moves along the angle bisector, the magnetic flux through each segment is reduced due to the angle bisector effect.
The induced EMF ε' in the modified configuration is given by ε' = (√2/2) × BLv.
The ratio of the induced EMF values is ε'/ε = (√2/2) × BLv / BLv = √2/2.
